response:
[start of motion plan]
The task is to break the wrist while grasping the wrist.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
- Object Properties: The relevant object appears to be a mechanical wrist joint connected to the robot end-effector. The joint likely consists of metal and plastic parts with moderate stiffness. The mass of the wrist joint assembly is estimated to be about 1.5 kg. The coefficient of static friction between the gripper material (likely rubber or soft plastic) and the wrist is around 0.6, ensuring a firm grasp without slipping. The joint to be broken is assumed to have a rotational resistance torque of roughly 5 to 10 N-m, common for wrist joints with small internal springs or friction washers.
- Environmental Factors: Gravity acts downward, so supporting forces along Z direction will be required. The working surface is a wooden table with a rough texture but the object is suspended by the gripper, so no direct table contact. There may be some damping or resistance in the wrist joint hinge mechanism to overcome. Friction between robot gripper and wrist must be high to avoid slip during forceful twisting.
- The relevant object is the robot wrist joint composed of metal/plastic, has mass ~1.5 kg, with a robot gripper static friction coefficient of 0.6.
- The surface of interaction is the rubberized gripper finger-pad to wrist local surface, with static friction coefficient of 0.6.
- Contact Types: A stable pinch grasp is maintained around the wrist, requiring forces normal to the wrist axis to prevent slipping. Contact is mostly surface area contact with some edge contact around the gripper tips.
- Motion Type: The main motion is rotational torque applied about the wrist joint axis to induce breakage. To do so, the robot must twist the wrist joint by applying torque along one of the rotational axes (likely the X or Y axis of the wrist frame). This may be combined with axial force to partially unload the joint or create tension.
- Contact Considerations: To maintain grasp without slip during the applied torque, the robot must exert normal gripping forces on the wrist and possibly small counter forces along other wrist linear axes to keep stable contact.
- Motion along axes: The robot exerts rotational torque primarily about the Rx axis to twist the wrist joint. A smaller positive linear force along Z axis is applied to slightly pull and create tension. Negative linear force along X and Y axes is minimal (no major translation), to keep grasp secure.
- Task duration: The breaking motion with torque application and grasping will take about 3 seconds to smoothly apply torque, observe breakage, and safely release.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: joint rotational resistance ~7 N-m, joint mass 1.5 kg, friction coefficient 0.6, grasp force needed to prevent slip ~10 N.
- Relevant equations: Torque = Force × Lever arm; frictional force = normal force × friction coefficient.
- Relevant assumptions: Uniform friction, the robot gripper can apply up to 50 N grasp force, no external environmental constraints other than gravity.
- Computations: To overcome 7 N-m torque resistance with an estimated lever arm of 0.08 m (typical wrist joint radius), required tangential force = 7 N-m / 0.08 m = 87.5 N tangential force from the gripper fingers; divided by two gripper fingers ~44 N per finger grip force adjusted for friction.
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 1.5 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.6 along the surface: To maintain grasp, normal gripping force must be at least 44 N per finger assuming friction coefficient 0.6. Applying a torque of about 7 N-m about X-axis (Rx) by twisting motion over 3 seconds should break the wrist joint connection.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To complete the task and based upon the estimation of no large translational motion required, the robot must exert no force along the X-axis with magnitude 0 N on the object in the image.
Linear Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon the estimation of stable grasp, the robot must exert no force along the Y-axis with magnitude 0 N on the object in the image.
Linear Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon axial slight tension applied to assist breakage, the robot must exert positive force along the Z-axis with magnitude 15 N on the object in the image.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon overcoming the joint's rotational resistance, the robot must exert angular clockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude 7 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon no required rotational torque in this axis, the robot must exert no torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 0 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon no required rotational torque in this axis, the robot must exert no torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 0 N-m on the object in the image.
Grasping force: Estimated force range of 40 to 50 N per finger is required to overcome friction and resist slip during torque application, thus total grasp force 80 to 100 N.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Robot mechanical wrist joint composed of metal and plastic, mass approx. 1.5 kg, rubberized gripper contact with static friction coefficient 0.6."

# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Apply rotational clockwise torque about X-axis (~7 N-m) combined with slight positive linear force along Z-axis (15 N) to break wrist joint, maintain no forces along X/Y linear axes, no other rotations."

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [0, 0, 15, -7, 0, 0]

# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 90

# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 3
```

[end of motion plan]
message:
Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to break the wrist while grasping the wrist.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
